In desperation, I call Nayana via WhatsApp. She was in the middle of dining (which I didn't know at the start of the call), but says she will call Amazon India once she has finished eating. "Sorry, Nayana!" Daylight burns even more. I wait. #MoreTeethGrinding

So as daylight continues to burn (did I mention I was on holiday and supposed to be having fun, in New York?), I try calling the toll-free Amazon India number. It rings with an unfamiliar tone ( I have no idea of its meaning), but remains resolutely unanswered. #BloodPressure

Why Amazon UK are incapable of contacting Amazon India to spare a customer wasted time and great inconvenience, remains a mystery which would probably stump even Sherlock Holmes. Instead, I was given the toll-free number for Amazon India Customer Service. #LosingTheWillToLive

Muttering darkly and grinding my teeth (sorry, dear dentist!), I call Amazon UK again. This time I speak to a lady, who was very polite. I cannot be sure, but based on her accent, she may actually have been based in India. She also said she could not contact Amazon India.

So, the offered "solution" I was given was that the Amazon UK rep would get Amazon India to call me. "Um, when...I am on holiday, in New York!" "Soon." An hour passes, no phone call. I waited in my apartment, rather than go out, in case I missed it. Daylight is burning.

The Amazon UK customer service person was very polite, but said he couldn't contact Amazon India. Why? That remains bafflingly unclear. Isn't "taking ownership" meant to be a customer service "thing", or did that go out in the noughties?

So, I speak to an Amazon (UK) human and describe the situation. "I'm on holiday, please help! Can you contact your colleagues in Amazon India and send me confirmation the matter has been resolved?" No, he couldn't. What the fork? #TheGoodPlace
Interesting Nudge by Amazon...never seen this earlier. #psychology #nudge #ecommerce #amazon #India
